I guess it's like the old song on chemo. Give enough to kill the cancer but not enough to kill the person.Interferon is produced by the body but no where near the amounts we take. Just look at what it does to many of our bodies while on tx. Yes, it kills the virus but what else does it do to us? That's why I harp a lot on the "risk/reward" thing and liver stage when people ask about treating or not. The only right decision is an informed decision and that means knowing not just the potential good of these drugs but their potential harm.-- Jim

It's very common for docs to recommend treatment to geno 2's withouth a biopsy. Reason is that it's a shorter (24 wk) tx with 80 percent chance of success, overall. That said, it's still a personal decision and if you have strong reservations about tx, getting a biopsy isn't a bad idea. If it turns out you have little or no liver damage, you might decide to wait a little and see what the newer treatments have in store.If you do decide to treat now - biopsy or not -- and it is very tempting with the high success rate -- consider the newer "short course" treatment.Two studies suggest the same success rate with 12 weeks of Peg Intron or 16 weeks of Pegasys as you would have with the standard 24 week treatment. The caveat is you have to be non-detectible at week 4, so following this route, a sensitive week 4 PCR test is a must.So again, if you clear at week 4, you treat another 8 weeks (if on Peg Intron) or another 12 weeks (if on Pegasys) and are done.If you don't clear at week 4, you then have two options. Either continue on with the standard 24 weeks of treatment, or simply bail out to fight another day, with perhaps another drug. In that scenario, you've only exposed yourself to 4 weeks of these meds.Just to be clear, the "stopping at week 4" is my own personal tx hypothetical extrapolated from I've read and experienced. Don't know any doctors advocating it, but it makes sense to me.-- Jim

I'll also add that in lieu of needle biopsy, two less invasive options exist. First, you can get a Fibrosure test from Labcorp. But a better option would be to make a day trip to Boston and have a Fibroscan test. You would contact Dr. Afdhal, Chief of Hepatology and Director of the Liver Center at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. He represents one of only three centers in the country now running FDA approval trials for Firbroscan. In addition to the Fibroscan test, you couldn't get a better consult than Dr. Afdhal with your tx issue.-- Jim
